Minutes - September 29, 1954
Page 6
The Committee reviewed state wide plans in North Carolina. The
State Television Commission has now requested legislative funds to
support studios at Chapel Hill, Greensboro and Raleigh. Studios at
these locations are to b© connected by means of microwave relay to a
transmitter so located to serve two-third® of the state’s population.
2. Developments in Miami: The Director reported on the develop¬
ments in Miami, In June of this year the School Board had applied to
the Federal Communication® Commission for an extension of its
construction permit which would expire July 12, 1954. The FCC did not
immediately grant this request. On September 8 the Commission directed
a letter to the School Board questioning the Board's intention to
build a station. As a result of this move by the FCC, the School
Board officially allocated $17,000 for the construction of a station
and voted an additional $50,000 to meet operational expenses. The
extension has now been granted.
3. Channel threat in Tampa-St, Petersburg: Mullen reported
that two competitive hearings have been held for two commercial VEF
channels in Tampa-St. Petersburg. Only one of the losers is reported
to be favorable to educational television. There has not been much
progress toward activation of the educational television channel
there, and there is a possibility that St. Petersburg's municipally-
owned UHF station might petition the FCC to make the reserved VHF
channel available for commercial use.
